doc.title: Need the response body

comments.body:
It is a general node.js question, but I'll answer anyway :)

The `response` object is an instance of `Readable` stream: http://nodejs.org/api/stream.html#stream_class_stream_readable . You should be able to receive `readable` event and to call `.read()` method on it.
comments.content:
It is a general node.js question, but I'll answer anyway :)

The `response` object is an instance of `Readable` stream: http://nodejs.org/api/stream.html#stream_class_stream_readable . You should be able to receive `readable` event and to call `.read()` method on it.
comments.author: indutny

comments.body:
Thanks Fedor for the answer. Sorry asked a general question.

It would be very nice for my application to get the event when the entire HTTP response body is received.  Wonder if it's possible?
comments.content:
Thanks Fedor for the answer. Sorry asked a general question.

It would be very nice for my application to get the event when the entire HTTP response body is received.  Wonder if it's possible?
comments.author: user1020

comments.body: Only with the use of modules, no such default event there. You should try talking about it [there](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/nodejs).
comments.content: Only with the use of modules, no such default event there. You should try talking about it [there](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/nodejs).

comments.body: Thanks. Will "create" one event by reading the readable stream then.
comments.content: Thanks. Will "create" one event by reading the readable stream then.

doc.title: Disable header compression.

comments.body:
Thanks for contributing it!

Do you think we could make it configurable, via both server and client options? I'm quite sure that there are some users who will benefit from having compression enabled.
comments.content:
Thanks for contributing it!

Do you think we could make it configurable, via both server and client options? I'm quite sure that there are some users who will benefit from having compression enabled.
comments.author: indutny

comments.body: Configurability sounds like a good idea. Some might be choosing spdy purely for the speed gains and switch to tls as a by product. Those people would not care if the stream leaks information.
comments.content: Configurability sounds like a good idea. Some might be choosing spdy purely for the speed gains and switch to tls as a by product. Those people would not care if the stream leaks information.
comments.author: Munter

comments.body:
This change is surely not the best solution. Chrome and Firefox seem to compress "whitelisted" headers but not other headers, specifically "Cookies:". I was just too lazy to write similar logic...
https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=779413#c6

Then how about disabling compression by default to be conservative about security, but make it configurable by an explicit option? Later we can implement sophisticated compression logic like browsers and make it default.
comments.content:
This change is surely not the best solution. Chrome and Firefox seem to compress "whitelisted" headers but not other headers, specifically "Cookies:". I was just too lazy to write similar logic...
https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=779413#c6

Then how about disabling compression by default to be conservative about security, but make it configurable by an explicit option? Later we can implement sophisticated compression logic like browsers and make it default.
comments.author: nya3jp

comments.body:
@nya3jp I don't think that we may want to patch zlib for this :) And this will certainly have bad consequences for some of the users, because we'll need to bundle patched zlib and that means problems on Windows.

Anyway, making it not compressed implicitly and providing an option to enable compression should be the best way to go.
comments.content:
@nya3jp I don't think that we may want to patch zlib for this :) And this will certainly have bad consequences for some of the users, because we'll need to bundle patched zlib and that means problems on Windows.

Anyway, making it not compressed implicitly and providing an option to enable compression should be the best way to go.
comments.author: indutny

comments.body: Another option is disable compression just for client side. Server side can be compression enabled by default. This is the way spdylay project uses.
comments.content: Another option is disable compression just for client side. Server side can be compression enabled by default. This is the way spdylay project uses.
comments.author: tatsuhiro-t

comments.body:
Hi all,

Thanks for your comments! I've updated the patch to accept a boolean option `headerCompression` to explicitly enable header compression.
I did not update README.rst intentionally to avoid users enabling compression without knowing what they're doing. I believe those really want to do it will look into the code anyway...

Tatsuhiro: Disabling compression only in client sounds interesting, but I'm not very sure it's really safe as I'm not a security expert (nor a SPDY expert... I've just started SPDY and even Node.js this week!). Is it widely accepted solution for CRIME or this kind of attacks?
comments.content:
Hi all,

Thanks for your comments! I've updated the patch to accept a boolean option `headerCompression` to explicitly enable header compression.
I did not update README.rst intentionally to avoid users enabling compression without knowing what they're doing. I believe those really want to do it will look into the code anyway...

Tatsuhiro: Disabling compression only in client sounds interesting, but I'm not very sure it's really safe as I'm not a security expert (nor a SPDY expert... I've just started SPDY and even Node.js this week!). Is it widely accepted solution for CRIME or this kind of attacks?

comments.body: Updated the patch.
comments.content: Updated the patch.

comments.body:
relevant discussion about server side compression:
https://groups.google.com/forum/#!searchin/spdy-dev/compression/spdy-dev/6mVYRv-lbuc/qGcW2ldOpt8J
comments.content:

comments.author: tatsuhiro-t

comments.body:
Basically, CRIME is attacking user by controlling the headers to transmit. The attacker generally has very little power doing this against server, as the above link says.
If you just use node-spdy for non-browser usage, then disabling compression does not enhance any security at all and just increase the data on the wire.
comments.content:

I'm fine with either way and follow the way the committers agree on. @indutny: what do you think?

doc.title: Don't close server push streams on associated stream's close.

comments.body:
I mean this part in the spec:
> The pushed streams do not need to be closed (FIN set) before the originating stream is closed, they only need to be created before the originating stream closes.

So new push can't be initiated after the associated stream is closed, but ongoing pushes are allowed to continue.
comments.content:
I mean this part in the spec:
> The pushed streams do not need to be closed (FIN set) before the originating stream is closed, they only need to be created before the originating stream closes.

So new push can't be initiated after the associated stream is closed, but ongoing pushes are allowed to continue.
comments.author: nya3jp

comments.body: I've stumbled into this problem as well. It meant that I had to create some async callbacks for each push request to finish before I end the original request stream. +1 for fixing this.
comments.content: I've stumbled into this problem as well. It meant that I had to create some async callbacks for each push request to finish before I end the original request stream. +1 for fixing this.

doc.body:
Hi Fedor,

I found current code does not allow server pushes after their associated stream is closed, while it is allowed in spec.
http://www.chromium.org/spdy/spdy-protocol/spdy-protocol-draft3-1#TOC-3.3.1-Server-implementation

Could you take a look please?

Thanks!
Shuhei / nya
doc.content:

Could you take a look please?

Thanks!
Shuhei / nya

Date response header is important but it was not provided.

Refs:
[RFC2616](http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2616.txt)
[lib/\_http\_outgoing.js#L230](https://github.com/joyent/node/blob/master/lib/_http_outgoing.js#L230)
http://nodejs.org/api/http.html#http_response_senddate

Thanks.

doc.title: Support for forcing spdy mode

comments.body:
@ohsc this is exactly the mode you are looking more, and even more it works just fine with our iOS library https://github.com/voxer/ispdy .

Could you please try verifying that you have setup it correctly? You could do it by:

1. `brew install spdylay`
2. `spdycat -v -3 https://your-host-name:<port-number/`

comments.body: Ok, I dig a little bit deeper into it and it seems to be a CocoaSPDY bug. It sends `SETTINGS_INITIAL_WINDOW_SIZE` set to `0`, and the fact that other servers are accepting this means only that they are broken.

doc.body:
hi, 
I'm using node-spdy work with CocoaSPDY which is  the SPDY client library for iOS. 
CocoaSPDY does not support NPN. It need a mode ignoring NPN and forcing SPDY with SSL.

I tried `{ plain: true, ssl: true}`. CocoaSPDY connectted to node-spdy successfully, however no response send to CocoaSPDY.

Please take a look at https://github.com/twitter/CocoaSPDY#a-note-on-npn 

Thank you.

doc.title: SPDY at Nodejitsu

comments.body:
I think that Nodejitsu's TLS terminator doesn't support SPDY. AFAIK, they have a set of _big_ proxies that are routing all incoming requests to specific apps. If you want to have a SPDY support for your server - it should be enabled on a global routing level.

Cheers,
Fedor.
comments.content:
I think that Nodejitsu's TLS terminator doesn't support SPDY. AFAIK, they have a set of _big_ proxies that are routing all incoming requests to specific apps. If you want to have a SPDY support for your server - it should be enabled on a global routing level.

Cheers,
Fedor.

comments.author: indutny

doc.body:
This is related to #123. We are using node-git and node-http-proxy#caronte. When using ordinary http and https, everything works as expected. When spdy is enabled, all requests have `method: null` instead of POST, GET, etc.

You can see this live at https://jira-nowaker.atlashost.eu:8443/browse/LSP-5. Just open Chrome console and run this:
`AJS.$.post('https://jira-nowaker.atlashost.eu:8443/rest/api/1.0/render')`
You will get `405 (Method Not Allowed)` because this REST end-point accepts only POST. `req.method` is null, [our logger reports](https://github.com/CodeCharmLtd/rush-http-proxy/blob/caronte/modules/logging.js#L95). The application that is behind the proxy interprets this as GET.

Since neither [node-http-proxy#caronte](https://github.com/nodejitsu/node-http-proxy/tree/caronte) nor [rush-http-proxy#caronte](https://github.com/CodeCharmLtd/rush-http-proxy/tree/caronte) alters `req.method` in any place, I believe request method is lost somewhere in node-spdy.

This is the output of access.log that [our logger](https://github.com/CodeCharmLtd/rush-http-proxy/blob/caronte/modules/logging.js#L95) reports:

    {"timestamp":1388118763703,"method":null,"httpVersion":"1.1","headers":{"host":"jira-nowaker.atlashost.eu:8443","accept":"*/*","accept-encoding":"gzip,deflate,sdch","accept-language":"pl,en-US;q=0.8,en;q=0.6","cache-control":"no-cache","content-length":"0","cookie":"cookies unrelevant","origin":"https://jira-nowaker.atlashost.eu:8443","pragma":"no-cache","referer":"https://jira-nowaker.atlashost.eu:8443/browse/LSP-5","user-agent":"my user agent","x-requested-with":"XMLHttpRequest","x-forwarded-for":"my ip","x-forwarded-port":"8443","x-forwarded-proto":"https"},"url":"/rest/api/1.0/render","statusCode":405,"responseTime":10}

Essentially, everything is in place except for request method.

@RushPL will be able to provide some minimal code later. If you are able to review it before it's provided, then it's great. Thanks.

comments.body:
Not sure if this is helpful, but I ran some profiling, and noticed node spending around 50% of the cpu time in this partial call tree (as opposed to TLS, `20.01% - _tickCallback (node.js:395)`):

````
50.33% - _tickCallback (node.js:395)
49.90% - args.(anonymous function) (node_modules\nodetime\lib\core\proxy.js:121)
48.55% - (anonymous function) (_stream_readable.js:400)
48.45% - emitReadable_ (_stream_readable.js:407)
48.32% - EventEmitter.emit (events.js:53)
47.77% - pipeOnReadable (_stream_readable.js:613)
47.69% - flow (_stream_readable.js:569)
36.57% - write (_stream_readable.js:574)
22.20% - Writable.write (_stream_writable.js:160)
22.03% - write (node_modules\spdy\lib\spdy\protocol\parser.js:69)
21.30% - execute (node_modules\spdy\lib\spdy\protocol\parser.js:188)
21.08% - (anonymous function) (node_modules\spdy\lib\spdy\protocol\parser.js:121)
20.98% - write (node_modules\spdy\lib\spdy\protocol\parser.js:69)
20.48% - execute (node_modules\spdy\lib\spdy\protocol\parser.js:188)
20.37% - onFrame (node_modules\spdy\lib\spdy\protocol\parser.js:219)
19.70% - EventEmitter.emit (events.js:53)
19.09% - handleFrame (node_modules\spdy\lib\spdy\connection.js:138)
19.07% - _recv (node_modules\spdy\lib\spdy\stream.js:733)
19.07% - socket.ondata (http.js:1965)
````

I also tried to reproduce with simple curl uploads to SPDY and TLS, but couldn't see any significant difference, so it may indeed be somehow related to XHR2.

comments.body:
Ok, I can tell you for sure that this issue is happening on the browser-side. If you'll try running following thing:

```
spdycat -H "Content-Type: multipart/form-data;boundary=123" --data pretty-big-1gb-file.raw  https://localhost:44300/upload
```

You'll see that it is running at the speed of 80 mb/sec, sending 10x less packets than both chromium and firefox. I guess firefox could be reusing some algorithmic parts of chromium spdy engine, resulting in low performance.

Even more evidence: with latest node.js, chromium is occupying 100% of one core, while node takes only 50-60%.
With spdycat both node and spdycat takes 100% CPU.

comments.author: silverwind

comments.body:
@silverwind no, they just wrap the same amount of data into more frames, which results in more load on client-side (browser) and on server-side (node.js). Window size affects stream control flow, i.e. client, after sending `windowSize` data, will wait until server will acknowledge receiving it.

Thank you for understanding! :)

doc.body:
I'm doing multipart/form-data uploads over XHR2 to a node server and noticed a pretty big performance drop (~80MB/s to ~2MB/s on localhost) by just switching from `require("https")` to `require("spdy")`. Download speeds seemed unaffected.

From a quick look in Process Explorer it seems the node process is fully eating a core during uploads and spending a lot of time in `node.exe!v8::OutputStream::GetOutputEncoding+0x2e6fc`. It isn't Windows-specific though, as I had it happen on a Linux server too. If you need any more details, just ask, or just take a look at my [app](https://github.com/silverwind/droppy).
doc.content:
I'm doing multipart/form-data uploads over XHR2 to a node server and noticed a pretty big performance drop (~80MB/s to ~2MB/s on localhost) by just switching from `require("https")` to `require("spdy")`. Download speeds seemed unaffected.

From a quick look in Process Explorer it seems the node process is fully eating a core during uploads and spending a lot of time in `node.exe!v8::OutputStream::GetOutputEncoding+0x2e6fc`. It isn't Windows-specific though, as I had it happen on a Linux server too. If you need any more details, just ask, or just take a look at my [app](https://github.com/silverwind/droppy).

I think It's reasonable to add an easy way to  redirect Http to https or spdy, although we can approach this by using nginx proxy or some other ways.

doc.body: This adds [ALPN](http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-tls-applayerprotoneg-03) support to node-spdy. ALPN is not in node yet, but there's a [node fork that supports it](https://github.com/shigeki/node/tree/alpn_support) (using a newer version of OpenSSL). The API seems to be very straightforward, and I expect it to be the API that node adopts in the future, too. Feel free to reject it if you think this is not the case.

doc.title: "Received rst: 3" when trying to use push.

comments.author: mape

comments.body:
Seems this is the cause: lib/spdy/response.js:113

    host = socket._spdyState.host || 'localhost',

Host always went to fallback 'localhost' so Cross Origin was triggered regardless of the address used.

After I changed this it all worked fine (except for when doing 120+ pushes of images but that is another issue.)

A bit hacky but works:

    host = socket._spdyState.host || socket._spdyState.options.headers.host || 'localhost',
comments.content:

    host = socket._spdyState.host || 'localhost',

After I changed this it all worked fine (except for when doing 120+ pushes of images but that is another issue.)

A bit hacky but works:

    host = socket._spdyState.host || socket._spdyState.options.headers.host || 'localhost',

--

Here the browser uses a single SPDY session and it seems that the `RST_STREAM` caused by the duplicated pushed content (`main.js`) is not handled by Node, ~~I was expecting to receive something in `if (err) return;`.~~

~~Is it just a matter of unhandled exception in node-spdy?~~

Ok, just figured out that the proper way to overcome this is to set the callback:

```javascript
stream.on('error', function (err) {
    /*...*/
});
```

If this is really the way to go, feel free to close this issue. I would spend some word on this in the README though, at least I would update the example.

doc.title: spdy push for 301 or 304

comments.body: Protocol doesn't allow it, and it doesn't seem to be really useful. Just push it, and if browser already aware of it - it might cancel the stream. Or, on other hand, you can opt-out and not push it at all.
comments.content: Protocol doesn't allow it, and it doesn't seem to be really useful. Just push it, and if browser already aware of it - it might cancel the stream. Or, on other hand, you can opt-out and not push it at all.
comments.author: indutny

comments.body:
Consider if I have a CSS file that has 10 dependencies, and it then has to do a 304 for each one, we are better off just resending the CSS file each time. If there was a way to say that the CSS file is not modified, as well as pushing not-modified responses for the 10 dependencies, it would save a lot of back and fourth here.

It's unfortunate push streams don't work completely down to the protocol level like this, equivalent to making a request. Because then this caching behaviour would be ideal.
comments.content:
Consider if I have a CSS file that has 10 dependencies, and it then has to do a 304 for each one, we are better off just resending the CSS file each time. If there was a way to say that the CSS file is not modified, as well as pushing not-modified responses for the 10 dependencies, it would save a lot of back and fourth here.

It's unfortunate push streams don't work completely down to the protocol level like this, equivalent to making a request. Because then this caching behaviour would be ideal.
comments.author: guybedford

comments.body: You should keep in mind, that you're not starting sending data (i.e. `.push()`'s callback isn't called) until the browser/client has acknowledged that he wants to receive data related to this PUSH stream. So, *the right way* to do it would be to just send them anyway and add etag header just in case.
comments.content: You should keep in mind, that you're not starting sending data (i.e. `.push()`'s callback isn't called) until the browser/client has acknowledged that he wants to receive data related to this PUSH stream. So, *the right way* to do it would be to just send them anyway and add etag header just in case.
comments.author: indutny

comments.body: Ok, thanks for clarifying. So if the etag was present, and matched the one already in the browser's cache, it wouldn't need to accept the push stream? That is very different to how I imagined it, and opens up some nice possibilities. Thanks for the help.
comments.content: Ok, thanks for clarifying. So if the etag was present, and matched the one already in the browser's cache, it wouldn't need to accept the push stream? That is very different to how I imagined it, and opens up some nice possibilities. Thanks for the help.

Do you think it's worth filing a bug report for this?

doc.body:
I just wanted to check if this is possible to push 301 and 304 responses?

The use case is that a request for a file results in say three other files being pushed.

If there is a new request for that file, and the etag still matches, then the other three files will also have matching etags, so it would make sense to push the 304 responses.

Push doesn't seem to give the option of a different status code. Would this work in theory or would the protocol not allow this?
doc.content:
I just wanted to check if this is possible to push 301 and 304 responses?

The use case is that a request for a file results in say three other files being pushed.

If there is a new request for that file, and the etag still matches, then the other three files will also have matching etags, so it would make sense to push the 304 responses.

Push doesn't seem to give the option of a different status code. Would this work in theory or would the protocol not allow this?

[0]: https://technotes.googlecode.com/git/nextprotoneg.html

comments.author: indutny

comments.body:
Ah, I think you got me wrong. Here's an example.

On my root server I have on IP address. Now one root server is pretty big for only one node app. I have about 10 different, isolated project running there. Each has it's own domain. To makle them all available on port 80 I have nginx configured to proxy all incomming requests on port 80 to different ports, based on the domain name.
```
my-domain.com:80   -> localhost:3001
example.com:80     -> localhost:3002
random.com:80      -> localhost:3003
foo-bar.com:80     -> localhost:3004
```

Now I want the same setup for port 443. nginx is capable of proxying TLS requests, but it wants to decrypt the connection first. I would need to make node-spdy expect already decrypted requests and leave all the TLS stuff up to nginx.

Is this even possible? Or would you route the requests with another tool? How do you do it?
comments.content:
Ah, I think you got me wrong. Here's an example.

On my root server I have on IP address. Now one root server is pretty big for only one node app. I have about 10 different, isolated project running there. Each has it's own domain. To makle them all available on port 80 I have nginx configured to proxy all incomming requests on port 80 to different ports, based on the domain name.
```

example.com:80     -> localhost:3002

```

Now I want the same setup for port 443. nginx is capable of proxying TLS requests, but it wants to decrypt the connection first. I would need to make node-spdy expect already decrypted requests and leave all the TLS stuff up to nginx.

Is this even possible? Or would you route the requests with another tool? How do you do it?
comments.author: silvinci

comments.body: Gotcha, you'll need to use `plain: true` option to run server behind TLS terminator like nginx. And start as many servers as you want, or run them on one port and use another npm module for express or whatever to switch requests based on `hostname` header.
comments.content: Gotcha, you'll need to use `plain: true` option to run server behind TLS terminator like nginx. And start as many servers as you want, or run them on one port and use another npm module for express or whatever to switch requests based on `hostname` header.

doc.body:
Would it be possible to change the underlying TLS server to a regular HTTP server?
I want to have multiple (different) HTTPS/SPDY apps running on the same system. For this I need to route the incomming HTTPS requests with nginx for example. Only problem is, that nginx et al require certificates and then decrypt the connection before routing it.

So, can we change the underlying server or do you incidentally know about a better way to route the incomming traffic? Preferably something that just reads the SNI field and doesn't do much modification?

doc.body:
I had to revert back to the previous version when I upgraded my site here - http://jspm.io/.

Some responses were just randomly closing the connection before finishing the streams. Sometimes a full script would load, other times it would be cut off.

It may have something to do with the order of having the push streams run at the same time as the main response stream (it seemed to happen for the push files more easily).

But I haven't been able to work out exactly what was going on. I will look into this further next week with more info, just a heads up that there are some serious issues in the release.

doc.title: Is it possible to use SPDY without HTTPS?

comments.body:
Its possible to make requests to `plain: true` spdy-server using `spdycat` cli utility, specifying protocol version explicitly (`-3` or `-2` and `--no-tls`). To use it from browser, you will need to start chrome with `--use-spdy=no-ssl` flag.

But please keep in mind, that SPDY is supposed to on TLS(SSL) server or behind TLS(SSL) terminator, and otherwise not-suitable for serving web-content.
comments.content:
Its possible to make requests to `plain: true` spdy-server using `spdycat` cli utility, specifying protocol version explicitly (`-3` or `-2` and `--no-tls`). To use it from browser, you will need to start chrome with `--use-spdy=no-ssl` flag.

But please keep in mind, that SPDY is supposed to on TLS(SSL) server or behind TLS(SSL) terminator, and otherwise not-suitable for serving web-content.

comments.author: indutny

doc.body:
If I run a server push of a resource that is already cached, the browser can abandon the stream being pushed, causing a stream error on the push stream.

The solution to this is to ensure that the push stream has an error event listener so that node doesn't throw a server error and cause the app to crash.

It should be possible to add a dummy event listener in the right place to avoid this natural error.

Perhaps simply add something like the following in `push_stream.js` before calling the push stream callback: `stream.on('error', function(){});`.

Just a suggestion to help those like me that don't know these things from spending too much time trying to trace it down.
doc.content:
If I run a server push of a resource that is already cached, the browser can abandon the stream being pushed, causing a stream error on the push stream.

The solution to this is to ensure that the push stream has an error event listener so that node doesn't throw a server error and cause the app to crash.

It should be possible to add a dummy event listener in the right place to avoid this natural error.

Perhaps simply add something like the following in `push_stream.js` before calling the push stream callback: `stream.on('error', function(){});`.

Just a suggestion to help those like me that don't know these things from spending too much time trying to trace it down.

doc.title: Server Hint

comments.body: Server hint is just a http header (which you can set in `res.writeHead()`) or html element (`link prefetch`). Nothing that could/should be done in node-spdy.
comments.content: Server hint is just a http header (which you can set in `res.writeHead()`) or html element (`link prefetch`). Nothing that could/should be done in node-spdy.
comments.author: indutny

doc.body:
This module is absolutely incredible. The fact that NodeJS is ahead of Nginx in implementation (server push being supported) is saying a lot about the state of Node these days! Thanks so much for this, it changes the game considerably.

I hate to add a another feature, but it would be really awesome if server hint could be supported (http://www.chromium.org/spdy/link-headers-and-server-hint). It should in theory be simple, but I wouldn't have the faintest idea of where to start with something like this myself.

doc.body: Let's say I have a **dummy** script like this: ```javascript var spdy = require('spdy'); var fs = require('fs'); var options = { key: fs.readFileSync(__dirname + '/keys/spdy-key.pem'), cert: fs.readFileSync(__dirname + '/keys/spdy-cert.pem'), ca: fs.readFileSync(__dirname + '/keys/spdy-ca.pem'), }; var html = fs.readFileSync('index.html'); var imgs = []; for (var i = 0; i < 10; i++) { imgs[i] = fs.readFileSync(i + '.jpg'); } function logic(req, res) { if (req.url === '/') { res.writeHead(200, {'Content-Type': 'text/html'}); res.end(html); } else if (req.url.match(/\/[0-9]/)) { var n = req.url[1]; res.writeHead(200, {'Content-Type': 'image/jpeg'}); res.end(imgs[n]); } } spdy.createServer(options, logic).listen(8443); ``` Where `index.html` is just a list of 10 `` tag, and each image is ~`800K`. Am I wrong if I expect to see in the SPDY event log in `chrome://net-internals` that the `SPDY_SESSION_RECV_DATA` events of the various streams (10 in this case) interleave? What I see is instead that, firstly each stream is created: ``` t=1370706783266 [st= 263] SPDY_SESSION_SYN_STREAM --> fin = true --> :host: xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx.xx:8443 :method: GET :path: /0.jpg :scheme: https :version: HTTP/1.1 accept: */* accept-encoding: gzip,deflate,sdch accept-language: it-IT,en-US;q=0.8 cache-control: no-cache pragma: no-cache referer: https://xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx.xx:8443/ user-agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/27.0.1453.110 Safari/537.36 --> stream_id = 3 --> unidirectional = false t=1370706783267 [st= 264] SPDY_SESSION_SYN_STREAM --> fin = true --> :host: xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx.xx:8443 :method: GET :path: /1.jpg :scheme: https :version: HTTP/1.1 accept: */* accept-encoding: gzip,deflate,sdch accept-language: it-IT,en-US;q=0.8 cache-control: no-cache pragma: no-cache referer: https://xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx.xx:8443/ user-agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/27.0.1453.110 Safari/537.36 --> stream_id = 7 --> unidirectional = false [...] ``` and then `SPDY_SESSION_RECV_DATA` events arrive serially: ``` t=1370706783332 [st= 329] SPDY_SESSION_SYN_REPLY --> fin = false --> :status: 200 OK :version: HTTP/1.1 content-type: image/jpeg --> stream_id = 3 --> unidirectional = false t=1370706783498 [st= 495] SPDY_SESSION_RECV_DATA --> fin = false --> size = 8184 --> stream_id = 3 t=1370706783498 [st= 495] SPDY_SESSION_RECV_DATA --> fin = false --> size = 8192 --> stream_id = 3 t=1370706783620 [st= 617] SPDY_SESSION_RECV_DATA --> fin = false --> size = 8192 --> stream_id = 3 [...] t=1370706790103 [st= 7100] SPDY_SESSION_SYN_REPLY --> fin = false --> :status: 200 OK :version: HTTP/1.1 content-type: image/jpeg --> stream_id = 5 --> unidirectional = false t=1370706790234 [st= 7231] SPDY_SESSION_RECV_DATA --> fin = false --> size = 8184 --> stream_id = 5 t=1370706790234 [st= 7231] SPDY_SESSION_RECV_DATA --> fin = false --> size = 8192 --> stream_id = 5 t=1370706790355 [st= 7352] SPDY_SESSION_RECV_DATA --> fin = false --> size = 8192 --> stream_id = 5 [...] t=1370706796835 [st=13832] SPDY_SESSION_SYN_REPLY --> fin = false --> :status: 200 OK :version: HTTP/1.1 content-type: image/jpeg --> stream_id = 7 --> unidirectional = false t=1370706796970 [st=13967] SPDY_SESSION_RECV_DATA --> fin = false --> size = 8184 --> stream_id = 7 t=1370706796970 [st=13967] SPDY_SESSION_RECV_DATA --> fin = false --> size = 8192 --> stream_id = 7 t=1370706797103 [st=14100] SPDY_SESSION_RECV_DATA --> fin = false --> size = 8192 --> stream_id = 7 [...] ``` That sounds strange to me since one goal of SPDY is to exactly avoid the HOL blocking of HTTP pipelining. And this doesn't happen with Apache `mod_spdy`. How can you explain this behavior?
doc.content: Let's say I have a **dummy** script like this: ```javascript var spdy = require('spdy'); var fs = require('fs'); var options = { key: fs.readFileSync(__dirname + '/keys/spdy-key.pem'), cert: fs.readFileSync(__dirname + '/keys/spdy-cert.pem'), ca: fs.readFileSync(__dirname + '/keys/spdy-ca.pem'), }; var html = fs.readFileSync('index.html'); var imgs = []; for (var i = 0; i < 10; i++) { imgs[i] = fs.readFileSync(i + '.jpg'); } function logic(req, res) { if (req.url === '/') { res.writeHead(200, {'Content-Type': 'text/html'}); res.end(html); } else if (req.url.match(/\/[0-9]/)) { var n = req.url[1]; res.writeHead(200, {'Content-Type': 'image/jpeg'}); res.end(imgs[n]); } } spdy.createServer(options, logic).listen(8443); ``` Where `index.html` is just a list of 10 `` tag, and each image is ~`800K`. Am I wrong if I expect to see in the SPDY event log in `chrome://net-internals` that the `SPDY_SESSION_RECV_DATA` events of the various streams (10 in this case) interleave? Linux x86_64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/27.0.1453.110 Safari/537.36 --> stream_id = 7 --> unidirectional = false [...] ``` and then `SPDY_SESSION_RECV_DATA` events arrive serially: ``` t=1370706783332 [st= 329] SPDY_SESSION_SYN_REPLY --> fin = false --> :status: 200 OK :version: HTTP/1.1 content-type: image/jpeg --> stream_id = 3 --> unidirectional = false t=1370706783498 [st= 495] SPDY_SESSION_RECV_DATA --> fin = false --> size = 8184 --> stream_id = 3 t=1370706783498 [st= 495] SPDY_SESSION_RECV_DATA --> fin = false --> size = 8192 --> stream_id = 3 t=1370706783620 [st= 617] SPDY_SESSION_RECV_DATA --> fin = false --> size = 8192 --> stream_id = 3 [...] t=1370706790103 [st= 7100] SPDY_SESSION_SYN_REPLY --> fin = false --> :status: 200 OK :version: HTTP/1.1 content-type: image/jpeg --> stream_id = 5 --> unidirectional = false t=1370706790234 [st= 7231] SPDY_SESSION_RECV_DATA --> fin = false --> size = 8184 --> stream_id = 5 t=1370706790234 [st= 7231] SPDY_SESSION_RECV_DATA --> fin = false --> size = 8192 --> stream_id = 5 t=1370706790355 [st= 7352] SPDY_SESSION_RECV_DATA --> fin = false --> size = 8192 --> stream_id = 5 [...] t=1370706796835 [st=13832] SPDY_SESSION_SYN_REPLY --> fin = false --> :status: 200 OK :version: HTTP/1.1 content-type: image/jpeg --> stream_id = 7 --> unidirectional = false t=1370706796970 [st=13967] SPDY_SESSION_RECV_DATA --> fin = false --> size = 8184 --> stream_id = 7 t=1370706796970 [st=13967] SPDY_SESSION_RECV_DATA --> fin = false --> size = 8192 --> stream_id = 7 t=1370706797103 [st=14100] SPDY_SESSION_RECV_DATA --> fin = false --> size = 8192 --> stream_id = 7 [...] ``` That sounds strange to me since one goal of SPDY is to exactly avoid the HOL blocking of HTTP pipelining. comments.author: misterdjules

doc.body:
Hi!

I built a very small prototype that sends HTTP GET requests from a SPDY client (implemented using https://github.com/nasss/spdy-client ) to a SPDY server implemented using node-spdy. The requests are sent indefinitely and can be sent concurrently. My goal is to make sure that both the server and the client are robust enough for my needs.

When I use a small number of concurrent requests, after a while (a few thousands requests total) an error is raised on the client that says:
````
events.js:72
        throw er; // Unhandled 'error' event
              ^
Error: incorrect header check
    at Zlib._binding.onerror (zlib.js:295:17)

````

When I increase the number of concurrent requests, the error happens earlier. For instance, with 10 concurrent GET requests, this zlib error is raised after a few hundreds requests.

I tried to track down the cause of this issue, but I think it might be too deep into node-spdy's implementation for me right now. However, I set up a Git repository that contains two programs, a client and a server, that will help you reproduce this issue. I would appreciate any help on this.

The repository can be found here: https://bitbucket.org/jgilli/spdy-zlib-issue/overview . Once you cloned it, here's how to reproduce the problem:
1) run npm install in the local repository.
2) enter _./node_spdy_server.js -p 4243 --plain_ to launch the server.
3) enter _./node_spdy_client.js -p 4243 --plain --requests 10_ to launch the client.

This will print a lot of output on the console, and usually I find it easier to launch the two programs in two separate terminals. The zlib error should be raised pretty quickly with _--requests 10_ . 

If you have any question, feel free to ask. Thank you!

comments.author: matthiasg

doc.body:
It seems node-spdy (or spdy per se) is not currently compatible with socket.io. 

The default example at least does not seem to work and produces no connection events. It does not crash either, but it wont work.

I am a little unclear on whether SPDY and WS should be compatible to begin with. But i dont see how SPDY can replace websockets as SPDY is handled transparently by the browser process and not by the application hosted within it. Thus i cannot really replace websocket applications with spdy. 

I do see spdy and ws as complementary though but until they can be used on the same ssl port i dont see how i can switch to using spdy as my primary protocol.

any thoughts on this ? am i wrong?
doc.content:
It seems node-spdy (or spdy per se) is not currently compatible with socket.io. 

The default example at least does not seem to work and produces no connection events. It does not crash either, but it wont work.

I am a little unclear on whether SPDY and WS should be compatible to begin with. But i dont see how SPDY can replace websockets as SPDY is handled transparently by the browser process and not by the application hosted within it. Thus i cannot really replace websocket applications with spdy. 

I do see spdy and ws as complementary though but until they can be used on the same ssl port i dont see how i can switch to using spdy as my primary protocol.

any thoughts on this ? am i wrong?

doc.title: Make scheduler wait for drain if connection.write() returns false.

comments.body: Thank you, landed in c712b0f.
comments.content: Thank you, landed in c712b0f.
comments.author: indutny

doc.body:
This should enforce stream priorities better than the original scheduler in some cases.

I'll try to explain this. The current scheduler collects chunks for a short time, and then writes them to the connection stream starting with the highest priority chunk. This time frame is very short, because the scheduler uses `process.nextTick()`, so the time frame is exactly one JavaScript 'turn', or 'tick'. This makes the scheduler almost useless if the incoming chunk are coming asynchronously (imagine two streams with different priorities emitting data asynchronously: the higher priority stream won't have higher bandwidth allocated).

This patch makes the scheduler behave exactly the same until there's no congestion (there's enough bandwidth for every stream), but when there is, then it uses a different strategy. When the connection stream signals that its buffer is full (`connection.write()` returns `false`)  then we don't write any more until the there's free buffer space in the connection stream. In this time frame, there may be high or low priority incoming chunks, those are queued up. When the connection stream is ready again, the we write the higher priority chunks first etc. until we can.

Unfortunately, this is not completely stable yet. I am building a forwarding proxy (spdy on one side, http on the other) using node-spdy, and I use that for testing. I tested the patch with the latest Chrome, and the connection sometimes hangs, but could not figure out why. I am not very familiar with the node-spdy code base, so if someone could take a look at this that would be great. I would be glad to improve this patch further if you find problems.
doc.content:
This should enforce stream priorities better than the original scheduler in some cases.

I'll try to explain this. The current scheduler collects chunks for a short time, and then writes them to the connection stream starting with the highest priority chunk. This time frame is very short, because the scheduler uses `process.nextTick()`, so the time frame is exactly one JavaScript 'turn', or 'tick'. This makes the scheduler almost useless if the incoming chunk are coming asynchronously (imagine two streams with different priorities emitting data asynchronously: the higher priority stream won't have higher bandwidth allocated).

This patch makes the scheduler behave exactly the same until there's no congestion (there's enough bandwidth for every stream), but when there is, then it uses a different strategy. When the connection stream signals that its buffer is full (`connection.write()` returns `false`)  then we don't write any more until the there's free buffer space in the connection stream. In this time frame, there may be high or low priority incoming chunks, those are queued up. When the connection stream is ready again, the we write the higher priority chunks first etc. until we can.

Unfortunately, this is not completely stable yet. I am building a forwarding proxy (spdy on one side, http on the other) using node-spdy, and I use that for testing. I tested the patch with the latest Chrome, and the connection sometimes hangs, but could not figure out why. I am not very familiar with the node-spdy code base, so if someone could take a look at this that would be great. I would be glad to improve this patch further if you find problems.

Therefore I think checking if connection supports spdy push (by checking `req.isSpdy`) is the right way to do.

doc.title: "Support node v0.8" actually broke it?

comments.body: I've look on issue, spdyproxy was using some private methods like `.lock` and `.unlock`, they're all prefixed with underscore now. There're two choices either stick to 1.3.9, or stop using private methods, or use `_lock` and `_unlock` (probably more changes is needed in order to make it work).
comments.content: I've look on issue, spdyproxy was using some private methods like `.lock` and `.unlock`, they're all prefixed with underscore now. There're two choices either stick to 1.3.9, or stop using private methods, or use `_lock` and `_unlock` (probably more changes is needed in order to make it work).
comments.author: indutny

doc.body:
See igrigorik/node-spdyproxy#10

v1.3.9 was working fine with node v0.8, but v1.4.0 no long does. I don't know what that `legacy` test and `DuplexStream` thing is doing, but it looks like the prime suspect to me.
doc.content:
See igrigorik/node-spdyproxy#10

v1.3.9 was working fine with node v0.8, but v1.4.0 no long does. I don't know what that `legacy` test and `DuplexStream` thing is doing, but it looks like the prime suspect to me.

doc.body:
Hey there,

When I create a SPDY server using the latest (`1.4.1`) version of this module and setting the `plain` option, visiting the page in the latest Chrome/Firefox will throw the following stack trace.

    ../node_modules/spdy/lib/spdy/zlib-pool.js:54
      self.pool[version].push(pair);
                         ^
    TypeError: Cannot call method 'push' of undefined
    at done (../node_modules/spdy/lib/spdy/zlib-pool.js:54:26)
    at Object.resetZlibStream (/Users/joelcox/Desktop/lab-5-spdy/node_modules/spdy/lib/spdy/utils.js:57:3)
    at Pool.put (../node_modules/spdy/lib/spdy/zlib-pool.js:50:14)
    at Socket.onclose (../node_modules/spdy/lib/spdy/server.js:291:10)
    at Socket.EventEmitter.emit (events.js:115:20)
    at Socket._destroy.destroyed (net.js:358:10)
    at process.startup.processNextTick.process._tickCallback (node.js:244:9)

This happens both for `spdy/2` and for `spdy/3`

    var spdyOptions = {
	    plain: 'spdy/3',
	    windowSize: 1024,
    };

    var spdyServer = spdy.createServer(spdyOptions, app);
    spdyServer.listen(8001);

Running the same Express application over an encrypted SPDY connection works as expected.

comments.body:
Alright, reproduced again just now. I made a test repo: https://github.com/ajacksified/node-spdy-test

(note: this version uses node-spdy 1.4.0)

I suppose it could *also* be an express issue. Lots of moving parts. It seems like it works on the first request, but hangs afterwards. Restarting node and Chrome doesn't appear to fix things. It only appears to happen in Chrome.

Also, this time it doesn't appear to send partial content anymore, but hangs the request. Forever loading for all files:

![Screen Shot 2013-01-24 at 1 44 58 PM](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/175515/95425/55800246-666f-11e2-93f6-0fdd8ab67eb3.png)

Update: I also unchecked `enable experimental spdy/3` from chrome://flags to no effect.
Update 2: tried another macbook with the same Chrome version, experiencing the same thing.
Update 3: tried with windows 7 with Chrome  24.0.1312.56, same symptoms.
Update 4: same thing with OSX / 26.0.1386.0 dev
Update 5: providing content with spdy createserver instead of express results in success, leading me to believe it's either express or a problem with spdy responding to multiple requests and closing appropriately.
comments.content:

comments.body:
Thank you very much for the help.
Attached is the server code.
Here is how I did the test, maybe my test methodology is not correct, which lead to the wrong result, I suspect.

1. compile the code to js, coffee -c spdyserver.coffee
2. node --expose_gc --trace_gc spdyserver.js
3. at client side, I am using spdylay client. tatsuhiro-t/spdylay
4. added some modification to example/spdycli.c to  pthread_create 1000 clients and make a request to local server.
5. control-c at client side to tear down all the connections.
6. request to server:/profile to trigger a gc and get heap diff..

I can attach spdylay client tomorrow...it's in my other machine.


    memwatch = require('memwatch')

    class SpdyServer
      constructor: (@name, @options) ->
        @self = @
        @server = spdy.createServer(keys, @onRequest).listen(@options.ssl_port)
        @server.on 'connect', (req, res) ->
            console.log 'server: client connected...'

        @server.on 'secureConnection', (socket) ->
            @socket = socket

        @hd = new memwatch.HeapDiff()

      @create : (options) ->
        return new SpdyServer('SpdyServer', options)

      onRequest : (req, res) =>
        re = /client/
        console.log 'getting req:', req.url
        if req.isSpdy
            path = req.url
            match = re.exec path
            if match
                console.log 'got request, do nothing....'
            else if path == '/profile'
                console.log 'taking profile'
                memwatch.gc()
                cb = =>
                    diff = @hd.end()
                    console.log 'heap dump :', JSON.stringify(diff, null, 2)
                setTimeout cb, 4000   # wait for gc to complete

    exports.SpdyServer = SpdyServer

    options = {}
    options.ssl_port = 9443
    server = SpdyServer.create(options)

Are you catching exception?

as you can see in the source posted above, express catches the error properly with app.use(function(err, req, res, next). This works perfectly while using the https module. If I use spdy, the error is not catchable anymore and the res.end() in the error handling method is not called. Just try the code by replacing the last line https.createServer(options, app).listen(port); with spdy.createServer(options, app).listen(port);

I haven't deep dived into spdy to much, but I think there must be an issue with sdpy ssl encrypting and the node crypto module. Maybe spdy does not catches errors properly? That would explain, why the res available after an error in crypto.

comments.author: JordanPotter

doc.body:
If I set `{secure: true}` for my cookies when using `express.session`, no cookies will be passed to the client.

Here's some simple code testing this:

```coffeescript
fs = require 'fs'
spdy = require 'spdy'
express = require 'express'

securityOptions = 
	key: fs.readFileSync 'keys/privatekey.pem'
	cert: fs.readFileSync 'keys/certificate.pem'
	ca: fs.readFileSync 'keys/certrequest.csr'

expressServer = express()
expressServer.use express.cookieParser()
expressServer.use express.session
	secret: 'super secret'
	cookie:
		path: '/'
		httpOnly: true
		secure: true  # COMMENT OUT THIS LINE AND THINGS WILL WORK

expressServer.get '/', (request, response) ->
	headers = 'content-type': 'application/javascript'
	response.push '/main.js', headers, (error, stream) ->
		throw error if error?
		stream.end 'alert("hello from push stream!");'
	response.end '<script src="/main.js"></script>'

server = spdy.createServer securityOptions, expressServer
server.listen 10443

console.log 'started server'
```
doc.content:
If I set `{secure: true}` for my cookies when using `express.session`, no cookies will be passed to the client.

Here's some simple code testing this:

```coffeescript
fs = require 'fs'
spdy = require 'spdy'
express = require 'express'

securityOptions = 
	key: fs.readFileSync 'keys/privatekey.pem'
	cert: fs.readFileSync 'keys/certificate.pem'
	ca: fs.readFileSync 'keys/certrequest.csr'

expressServer = express()
expressServer.use express.cookieParser()
expressServer.use express.session
	secret: 'super secret'
	cookie:
		path: '/'
		httpOnly: true
		secure: true  # COMMENT OUT THIS LINE AND THINGS WILL WORK

expressServer.get '/', (request, response) ->
	headers = 'content-type': 'application/javascript'
	response.push '/main.js', headers, (error, stream) ->
		throw error if error?
		stream.end 'alert("hello from push stream!");'
	response.end '<script src="/main.js"></script>'

server = spdy.createServer securityOptions, expressServer
server.listen 10443

console.log 'started server'
```

comments.body: Found the node.js issue where the support was added: https://github.com/joyent/node/issues/2727
comments.content: Found the node.js issue where the support was added: https://github.com/joyent/node/issues/2727
comments.author: igrigorik

comments.body:
Hmm, ok.. After some searching, found the fix, had to change the order of preferred ciphers to: `RC4-SHA:RC4:ECDHE-RSA-AES256-SHA:AES256-SHA:HIGH:!MD5:!aNULL:!EDH:!AESGCM`. To be completely honest, not 100% sure on the implications of this. 

The cert and keys itself was generated through StartSSL guide.. which probably means I'm hardly the only one with this problem. May be worth documenting in node docs, in addition to current recommendations: http://nodejs.org/api/tls.html#tls_tls_createserver_options_secureconnectionlistener

/cc @bminer

comments.body:
Right, look at the cipher suites differences:

spdy.io:
```
TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_256_CBC_SHA (0x35)	256
TLS_RSA_WITH_RC4_128_SHA (0x5)	128
```

caseclose.com
```
TLS_RSA_WITH_RC4_128_SHA (0x5)	128
TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_256_CBC_SHA (0x35)	256
```

RC4 comes first for you, which is why it's marked as not vulnerable. So, your server (lighty?) is prioritizing RC4 over AES256.

doc.body:
Hello,

today I tried to setup `express` with `spdy`. I set up `express-spdy` and tried to store something in a session. Unfortunately that didn't work out as expected. We managed to track the bug down to `spdy` in [express](irc://irc.freenode.net/express).

Consider [this](https://gist.github.com/bc0f1ef2d150d260eb42) rather minimal example. (cf. [this](https://github.com/visionmedia/express/blob/master/examples/session/index.js))

``` bash
mkdir issue
cd issue
mkdir keys
npm install express spdy
```

You may want to generate `spdy-key.pem`, `spdy-csr.pem` and `spdy-crt.pem` in `keys/` using

```
cd ./keys/
openssl genrsa -out spdy-key.pem 4096
openssl req -new -key spdy-key.pem -out spdy-csr.pem
openssl x509 -req -days 3650 -in spdy-csr.pem -signkey spdy-key.pem -out spdy-cert.pem
```

Then place `app.js` from the gist in `issue` and run:

```
node app.js
```

Switching the variable `spdy` in line 1 of `app.js` toggles the use of `https`/`spdy`. Just navigate to [localhost:3000](https://localhost:3000/) and refresh. You'll only see the number of views increasing only when using `https`, which means that something in `spdy` is messed up.

Of course, that's not a basic use of `spdy`, but I don't have time to dive into the `express` session code ...

Please keep me updated if you fix this, because I#d really like to use your module :)

doc.title: failed to make examples/twitlog work

comments.body:
This is an ntwitter error. See the configuration section in https://npmjs.org/package/ntwitter and update `twitlog/realtime/index.js` accordingly.

If you want a simple express server, you can (more or less) follow the instructions at http://japhr.blogspot.com/2012/04/edge-spdy-nodejs-and-expressjs.html. An overview:

```
npm install -g express@2.x
express express-spdy
cd express-spdy
```

Now tune for spdy.  Update package.json (include the spdy dependency):

```javascript
{
    "name": "application-name"
  , "version": "0.0.1"
  , "private": true
  , "dependencies": {
      "express": "2.5.11"
    , "jade": ">= 0.0.1"
    , "spdy": "1.3.x"
  }
}
```
Change app.js to do SPDY and to pull in SSL keys (require `fs`, `spdy` and add `options` and new `spdy.createServer()`):

```javascript
var express = require('express')
  , spdy = require('spdy')
  , fs = require('fs')
  , routes = require('./routes');

//var app = module.exports = express.createServer();
var options = {
  key: fs.readFileSync(__dirname + '/keys/spdy-key.pem'),
  cert: fs.readFileSync(__dirname + '/keys/spdy-cert.pem'),
  ca: fs.readFileSync(__dirname + '/keys/spdy-csr.pem')
};

var app = spdy.createServer(express.HTTPSServer, options);
...
```

Then finalize install:

```
npm install
mkdir keys
cp node_modules/spdy/keys/* keys
```

With that, regular `node app` should start up a spdy server on https://localhost:3000.

comments.body:
@eee-c from what I can see, the req.url is set elsewhere (and works as is). The code in protocol.js simply copies the path header into "url" header, which we don't want to do anyway - it should removed.

https://github.com/indutny/node-spdy/blob/spdy-v3/lib/spdy/protocol/v3/protocol.js#L50-52

SPDY v2 passed "url" header which included the full url: {scheme, host, path}. That was deprecated in v3 in favor of separate :host, :scheme, :host, :path (path includes query). We shouldn't carry over the "url" header into v3.

@indutny is there anything special to run the tests? Fail outright for me..

```
> spdy@1.2.0 test /git/spdyproxy/node_modules/spdy
> mocha --ui tdd --growl --reporter spec test/unit/*-test.js

  A Framer of SPDY module
    frame parsing
      ◦ given a SYN_STREAM should return correct frame: Assertion failed: (ctx->dictionary_ != NULL && "Stream has no dictionary"), function Process, file ../src/node_zlib.cc, line 160.
```

comments.body: What are you using for the upstream app?  Node-spdy doesn't establish the request / response objects, but re-uses and decorates them. Still, I can't think why an upstream app wouldn't have a socket associated with it -- especially if it had called writeHead...
comments.content: What are you using for the upstream app?  Node-spdy doesn't establish the request / response objects, but re-uses and decorates them. Still, I can't think why an upstream app wouldn't have a socket associated with it -- especially if it had called writeHead...
comments.author: eee-c

comments.body:
Tracked it down... Turns out node's handling of `upgrade` and `connect` currently exposes a different API: 
https://github.com/joyent/node/pull/3036

Current API: https://github.com/joyent/node/commit/08a91acd76cd107dc2f3914f9ea7e277bb85206e#L2R56

With that, got my code to work. Annoying, because I have to replicate the SYN_REPLY frame construction in my server, but does the trick. Speaking of which, we need to extend node-spdy to emit `connect` events -- I'll open a separate pull for that.
comments.content:

doc.body: Just a couple of minor updates that I came across while playing with the 1.2 codebase...
doc.content: Just a couple of minor updates that I came across while playing with the 1.2 codebase...

doc.title: SPDY/3

comments.body:
K, here's a list, just fyi (SPDY/3->7)

      Addition of flow control

      Increased 16 bit length fields in SYN_STREAM and SYN_REPLY to 32
      bits.

      Changed definition of compression for DATA frames

      Updated compression dictionary

      Fixed off-by-one on the compression dictionary for headers

      Increased priority field from 2bits to 3bits.

      Removed NOOP frame

      Split the request "url" into "scheme", "host", and "path"

      Added the requirement that POSTs contain content-length.

      Removed wasted 16bits of unused space from the end of the
      SYN_REPLY and HEADERS frames.

      Fixed bug: Priorities were described backward (0 was lowest
      instead of highest).

      Fixed bug: Name/Value header counts were duplicated in both the
      Name Value header block and also the containing frame.
comments.content:
K, here's a list, just fyi (SPDY/3->7)

      Addition of flow control

      Increased 16 bit length fields in SYN_STREAM and SYN_REPLY to 32
      bits.

      Changed definition of compression for DATA frames

      Updated compression dictionary

      Fixed off-by-one on the compression dictionary for headers

      Increased priority field from 2bits to 3bits.

      Removed NOOP frame

      Split the request "url" into "scheme", "host", and "path"

      Added the requirement that POSTs contain content-length.

      Removed wasted 16bits of unused space from the end of the
      SYN_REPLY and HEADERS frames.

      Fixed bug: Priorities were described backward (0 was lowest
      instead of highest).

      Fixed bug: Name/Value header counts were duplicated in both the
      Name Value header block and also the containing frame.

comments.body:
Actually no.

If and only if the request came in via SPDY (as opposed to via plain SSL fallback) and the Transfer-Encoding header says chunked and there is no Content-Length then node-spdy needs to remove the Transfer-Encoding header, and buffer the response to calculate the Content-Length header which is then set.

Luckily I have implemented this behavior in [this module](https://github.com/phidelta/node-http-unchunk-stack) so that all that is necessary is that in case the request is a SPDY request, you wrap the response.

I have done this in my [spdy-proxy](https://github.com/phidelta/spdy-proxy) since writing this issue, the question is, whether this should go directly into node-spdy since it is really a fix to correct http responses to conform with SPDY requirements.

(P.S.: If you want me to I'll fork node-spdy and add this. I can then give you a pull request. I'm just asking whether that is the way you want to go.)

Luckily I have implemented this behavior in [this module](https://github.com/phidelta/node-http-unchunk-stack) so that all that is necessary is that in case the request is a SPDY request, you wrap the response.

comments.body:
Except that it then is trivial to output malformed responses from regular handlers by not setting Content-Length. 

This is generally accepted behavior, because node will make a chunked response of it in plain HTTPS. So if you have any existing handlers, you cannot use them with node-spdy. 

Example: you use node-spdy with express. Express will very likely output a response without a Content-Length which will be invalid spdy. So unless you wrap express with my module, you could not use express. 

The same holds true for any middleware that has not been explicitly designed for SPDY.

doc.body:
Hi Fedor,

I deployed a proxy server powered by node-spdy and tested it with Chrome and everything works great. After that I tested it with Firefox 11 (which now has SPDY but disabled). I enabled SPDY and tried it against the node-spdy proxy. The server that is being proxied used the "Transfer-Encoding: chunked" header and did not provide a "Content-Length" header, which made Firefox Croak.

I then filed a [bug with Firefox](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=736023), but the guys there pointed me at the [SPDY specification](http://dev.chromium.org/spdy/spdy-protocol/spdy-protocol-draft2) which states that: **Chunked encodings in spdy/2 are not valid**.

The question then arises at which level this needs to be fixed. Mozilla obviously is of the opinion that the specification is king, so they will not fix it in the browser. On the other hand, I can't ask the downstream server to avoid chunked encoding, since I may not even be mine. So there remain 2 possible places:

 1. The proxy (I use node-proxy for this)
 2. The SPDY Implementation (node-spdy)

I personally think that node-spdy would be the right place to do this. Since it has the same general properties as the built in HTTPS server and the adoption will only ever happen if it is trivial to use this via node. This is also the reason that the built in HTTP server does the same when the HTTP version of the client is below 1.1.

Basic research has shown me that since I don't know the content-length at the time of writeHead() I would need to intercept that call and then buffer the result that is written by write() and then tally the total-length on end() and set "Transfer-Encoding: identity" and "Content-Length". Then writeHead() for real and write() all the chunks and call end();

The only disadvantage of this approach is that I need to buffer the entire reply, which may be a lot of memory if there are a lot of requests.

The question is are you interested in me creating a patch that does this and are there any guidelines you want to apply if you do.

Regards,
Phil
doc.content:
Hi Fedor,

I deployed a proxy server powered by node-spdy and tested it with Chrome and everything works great. After that I tested it with Firefox 11 (which now has SPDY but disabled). I enabled SPDY and tried it against the node-spdy proxy. The server that is being proxied used the "Transfer-Encoding: chunked" header and did not provide a "Content-Length" header, which made Firefox Croak.

I then filed a [bug with Firefox](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=736023), but the guys there pointed me at the [SPDY specification](http://dev.chromium.org/spdy/spdy-protocol/spdy-protocol-draft2) which states that: **Chunked encodings in spdy/2 are not valid**.

The question then arises at which level this needs to be fixed. Mozilla obviously is of the opinion that the specification is king, so they will not fix it in the browser. On the other hand, I can't ask the downstream server to avoid chunked encoding, since I may not even be mine. So there remain 2 possible places:

 1. The proxy (I use node-proxy for this)
 2. The SPDY Implementation (node-spdy)

I personally think that node-spdy would be the right place to do this. Since it has the same general properties as the built in HTTPS server and the adoption will only ever happen if it is trivial to use this via node. This is also the reason that the built in HTTP server does the same when the HTTP version of the client is below 1.1.

Basic research has shown me that since I don't know the content-length at the time of writeHead() I would need to intercept that call and then buffer the result that is written by write() and then tally the total-length on end() and set "Transfer-Encoding: identity" and "Content-Length". Then writeHead() for real and write() all the chunks and call end();

The only disadvantage of this approach is that I need to buffer the entire reply, which may be a lot of memory if there are a lot of requests.

The question is are you interested in me creating a patch that does this and are there any guidelines you want to apply if you do.

Regards,
Phil

comments.body:
Alright, I think I understand better what you meant. Thank you for the clarification!

However, while I agree that a SPDY client is not imminently needed for end users, I think the "testing" use case is very important. When writing tests suites for a project that uses a SPDY server in its implementation, having a SPDY client or a high-level, robust and mature SPDY client library usable directly in Node would be very helpful. I don't know node-spdy's code base at all, and I'm even totally new to Node and SPDY, but it could even make node-spdy's server-test.js script a bit less cryptic and hardcoded.

Also, not everyone fall in the typical use case, and the number of non-typical uses of SPDY might be larger than we imagine. For instance, I recently worked on a Node project for a large company that wanted to use SPDY as a core component of its infrastructure. The plan was to use SPDY to multiplex thousands of HTTP requests (some pretty large, some very small) into one Web Socket tunnel, while maintaining good responsiveness for each request. We didn't need all that SPDY has to offer, we were interested mostly in using its framing layer.

We had to come up with a prototype in a few days and unfortunately, we ran into a few issues with the spdy-client library that prevented us from choosing SPDY as a viable solution. We could have spend a couple more days to fix these problems. Due to time constraints we ended using BinaryJS and its multiplexing abilities.

In that case, having a robust SPDY client library available may have allowed us to keep using SPDY. Of course, it's only one project with a use case that might be a bit different than the typical one, but it would be a shame that the absence of such a library cause more Node projects to to not choose SPDY for their implementation.

I don't know node-spdy's code base at all, and I'm even totally new to Node and SPDY, but it could even make node-spdy's server-test.js script a bit less cryptic and hardcoded.

Also, not everyone fall in the typical use case, and the number of non-typical uses of SPDY might be larger than we imagine. For instance, I recently worked on a Node project for a large company that wanted to use SPDY as a core component of its infrastructure. The plan was to use SPDY to multiplex thousands of HTTP requests (some pretty large, some very small) into one Web Socket tunnel, while maintaining good responsiveness for each request. We didn't need all that SPDY has to offer, we were interested mostly in using its framing layer.

We had to come up with a prototype in a few days and unfortunately, we ran into a few issues with the spdy-client library that prevented us from choosing SPDY as a viable solution. We could have spend a couple more days to fix these problems. Due to time constraints we ended using BinaryJS and its multiplexing abilities.

In that case, having a robust SPDY client library available may have allowed us to keep using SPDY. Of course, it's only one project with a use case that might be a bit different than the typical one, but it would be a shame that the absence of such a library cause more Node projects to to not choose SPDY for their implementation.
comments.author: misterdjules

comments.body:
I've just reached a point where I'm starting to need node balancing of SPDY.... issue is that there is nothing available now!

If we had a SPDY client, then it would be possible to have a master SPDY client balance across child servers. Not even nginx have got to this yet, so it's certainly understandable. But interestingly this module and method would become the preferable proxy option over nginx if we had this support!

comments.body:
Glad that you asked ;) I'll publish it here and then add some info to README.

First of all, I'm going to make chat example work. It's using socket.io long-polling and I don't know why, but it doesn't seem to work at all (probably SPDY problems in browser or anything...)

Next one will be server push support. It was implemented by @eee-c in previous major release, but since I rewrote current one - it was gone.

So what's working now:

* SPDY Server
* HTTPS fallback
* Just added tests (today)

When trying to execute a test, I get :

Error: Cannot find module './zlib_bindings'
    at Function._resolveFilename (module.js:320:11)

snooping with dtrace shows that node tries to find a package.json

  501  86597 node          -1 /usr/local/lib/node_modules/zlibcontext/lib/zlib_bindings/package.json 

I am not sure of the proper way to ask node to search for a binary extension.

doc.title: Node 0.5 Support

comments.body: Node-spdy now supports node 0.6 so this is no longer an issue.
comments.content: Node-spdy now supports node 0.6 so this is no longer an issue.
comments.author: eee-c

doc.body:
The test/spdy-server.js (and test/spdy-push-server.js) sample apps will not work with node 0.5.   Actually, I think they will, but connect will not install for node >0.5 and TJ [does not plan to let it](https://github.com/senchalabs/connect/pull/316).  More info at http://japhr.blogspot.com/2011/07/spdy-express-and-nodejs-050.html.

This is not a *huge* deal for node-spdy.  The sample app described in the README should still work, but making anything more sophisticated than that will be complicated.
doc.content:
The test/spdy-server.js (and test/spdy-push-server.js) sample apps will not work with node 0.5. More info at http://japhr.blogspot.com/2011/07/spdy-express-and-nodejs-050.html.

This is not a *huge* deal for node-spdy.  The sample app described in the README should still work, but making anything more sophisticated than that will be complicated.

comments.body:
Few comments for code style and commit message style.
Please, do not put spaces after/before "{", "}". Use 4-space width indentation if you're splitting long line in two or more.
Please, put [topic] before you commit message, where topic could be: zlib, response, request, core, etc.

Thanks for pull request! :)
comments.content:

comments.author: indutny

doc.body:
I believe that data compression is broken.  Thanks to some [comments from Mike Belshe](http://japhr.blogspot.com/2011/06/compressing-spdy-data-frames.html#comments), I think I have it worked out.

My main goal here was to ensure that the behavior of "new ZLib()" remained unchanged.  The implementation to achieve this could probably be cleaner.

Not sure what's up with the 2 upstream commits coming along for the ride here.  They are just a result of my resyncing my fork with idutny/node-spdy and contain no changes.
doc.content:
I believe that data compression is broken.  Thanks to some [comments from Mike Belshe](http://japhr.blogspot.com/2011/06/compressing-spdy-data-frames.html#comments), I think I have it worked out.

My main goal here was to ensure that the behavior of "new ZLib()" remained unchanged.  The implementation to achieve this could probably be cleaner.

Not sure what's up with the 2 upstream commits coming along for the ride here.  They are just a result of my resyncing my fork with idutny/node-spdy and contain no changes.

comments.body:
That means that you're not compiling node against the openssl that you compiled/installed per the node-spdy README.

Just to be clear, you need to compile/install openssl from the cvs server and then re-run the node.js config -- explicitly setting the --openssl-includes and --openssl-libpath command-line switches.

FWIW, I took notes the last time I had to install this: http://japhr.blogspot.com/2011/06/setting-up-node-spdy.html.  That may note apply directly to what you are trying to do. I installed both node.js and openssl in my local directory.  I was also compiling for 64 bit, so openssl needed some additional configuration.  Lastly, I was installing my fork, not the real node-spdy.  Still, that post may be of some use.

comments.body:
The compiler is still not finding the newly installed openssl.

Something is wrong with the options you are passing to configure.  libpath needs to end in "lib".  So it should be:

     ./configure --openssl-includes=/usr/local/ssl/include --openssl-libpath=/usr/local/ssl/lib

You might also try a `make distclean` and then re-run configure with these options.  Shouldn't be necessary, but can't hurt.

If you keep getting the same error, what does `ls -l /usr/local/ssl/lib` return?
comments.content:
The compiler is still not finding the newly installed openssl.

Something is wrong with the options you are passing to configure.  libpath needs to end in "lib".  So it should be:

     ./configure --openssl-includes=/usr/local/ssl/include --openssl-libpath=/usr/local/ssl/lib

You might also try a `make distclean` and then re-run configure with these options.  Shouldn't be necessary, but can't hurt.

If you keep getting the same error, what does `ls -l /usr/local/ssl/lib` return?
comments.author: eee-c

comments.body: @eee-c strange thing is that it can't find `SSL_CTX_set_next_proto_select_cb`, because it's behind `#ifdef` to be compatible with older openssl versions
comments.content: @eee-c strange thing is that it can't find `SSL_CTX_set_next_proto_select_cb`, because it's behind `#ifdef` to be compatible with older openssl versions
comments.author: indutny

comments.body: @indutny the `#ifdef` may be passing because the `--openssl-includes` is pointing to the correct headers.  But the linker is likely still pulling in the system openssl `.so` (e.g. from /usr/lib) which does not have that symbol.  That would be my guess, at least.
comments.content: @indutny the `#ifdef` may be passing because the `--openssl-includes` is pointing to the correct headers.  But the linker is likely still pulling in the system openssl `.so` (e.g. from /usr/lib) which does not have that symbol.  That would be my guess, at least.

comments.body:
@hynese That means that you will have to run configure with `lib` appended to the libpath:  `./configure --openssl-includes=/usr/local/ssl/include --openssl-libpath=/usr/local/ssl/lib`

BUT...

First you need some openssl shared objects in there.  I believe that you need to go back into the openssl source and reconfigure/rebuild/re-install:

```
./Configure shared
make depend
make
sudo make install
```
comments.content:
@hynese That means that you will have to run configure with `lib` appended to the libpath:  `./configure --openssl-includes=/usr/local/ssl/include --openssl-libpath=/usr/local/ssl/lib`

BUT...

First you need some openssl shared objects in there.  I believe that you need to go back into the openssl source and reconfigure/rebuild/re-install:

```
./Configure shared
make depend
make
sudo make install
```

comments.body:
Here's the process I've been following:

#On my Ubuntu 11.04 32-bit:

#First install openssl off the head:
cvs -d anonymous@cvs.openssl.org:/openssl-cvs co openssl
./configure
make
sudo make install

#Now install node:
git clone git://github.com/joyent/node.git
git checkout 9812e31e8ba43be9c50d07f83cbf459427a5d877
./configure --openssl-includes=/usr/local/ssl/include/openssl --openssl-libpath=/usr/local/ssl
make
sudo make install

#Now install node-spdy:
git clone git://github.com/eee-c/node-spdy.git
npm install vows
npm install libzcontext

#Test node-spdy:
cd node-spdy
cd test
node spdy-server.js

node.js:181
        throw e; // process.nextTick error, or 'error' event on first tick
        ^
You're using not NPN-enabled version of node.js

doc.title: Piped streams are destroyed when connections are terminated.
doc.body:
Just need to add an empty destroy() method to Parser.  Prevents a crash due to a "no method" error.

There are a couple of ways to trip it, but the easiest is to close the browser.

doc.title: SETTINGS frames are not little endian

comments.body:
Thanks for your participation, I'll keep open this pull request for now.
The reason for doing that, is that Chrome reads those bytes in little-endian byte order. I'd talked to guys from Chromium and they're going to fix it with new release of Chrome.

Because all SPDY servers are working that manner now, I'll copy their behaviour.
comments.content:
Thanks for your participation, I'll keep open this pull request for now.
The reason for doing that, is that Chrome reads those bytes in little-endian byte order. I'd talked to guys from Chromium and they're going to fix it with new release of Chrome.

Because all SPDY servers are working that manner now, I'll copy their behaviour.
comments.author: indutny

doc.body:
Per all versions of the SPDY spec, the ID in SETTTINGS frames should be network order.  Furthermore, in draft 2, the first octet in an ID is a control, not the ID.  As written, node-spdy puts the ID in the first octet.

That said, I checked this out in about:net-internals and find that Chrome (13.0.767.1 dev) does not seem to honor my understanding of the spec.  And, in fact, it works with the little-endian way of doing it.

So this pull request has two purposes: (1) to align with the spec -- whenever Chrome decides to do so and (2) ask you how the heck you knew to try little-endian :)
doc.content:
Per all versions of the SPDY spec, the ID in SETTTINGS frames should be network order.  Furthermore, in draft 2, the first octet in an ID is a control, not the ID.  As written, node-spdy puts the ID in the first octet.

That said, I checked this out in about:net-internals and find that Chrome (13.0.767.1 dev) does not seem to honor my understanding of the spec.  And, in fact, it works with the little-endian way of doing it.

So this pull request has two purposes: (1) to align with the spec -- whenever Chrome decides to do so and (2) ask you how the heck you knew to try little-endian :)
