doc.title: Default flow control

comments.body:
It is a default behavior to split all outgoing data into 8kb chunks and interleave them. If it appears to be happening in a serial order instead of parallel, it basically means that server is observing `favicon` request after finishing the PUSH request.

It should be possible to verify such condition in your application's code by adding some logging.
comments.content:
It is a default behavior to split all outgoing data into 8kb chunks and interleave them. If it appears to be happening in a serial order instead of parallel, it basically means that server is observing `favicon` request after finishing the PUSH request.

It should be possible to verify such condition in your application's code by adding some logging.
comments.author: indutny

comments.body: I just added some logs, and I'm definitely seeing the 400 response being sent out immediately after the push.
comments.content: I just added some logs, and I'm definitely seeing the 400 response being sent out immediately after the push.
comments.author: guybedford

doc.body:
It makes very little sense for me to set stream priorities for my specific application because everything is equally important.

In this scenario, what matters is that a single large request doesn't block lots of small requests.

But in testing the push functionality, I noticed that if I push a 3MB file, the browser requests the favicon.ico just as the packets start arriving. And it seems to consistently only get the 404 response for the favicon after the full push stream has completed (over six seconds later).

Surely the default behaviour here should be to allow the smaller request to immediately be sent back instead of letting the push stall everything else?
doc.content:
It makes very little sense for me to set stream priorities for my specific application because everything is equally important.

In this scenario, what matters is that a single large request doesn't block lots of small requests.

But in testing the push functionality, I noticed that if I push a 3MB file, the browser requests the favicon.ico just as the packets start arriving. And it seems to consistently only get the 404 response for the favicon after the full push stream has completed (over six seconds later).

Surely the default behaviour here should be to allow the smaller request to immediately be sent back instead of letting the push stall everything else?

doc.title: Stream chunk size inconsistent

comments.body:
The question is, how much of the data was __actually__ sent by the server, before it has received the RST. Considering the latency, it could be that server has sent most of the data (or all of it) and only then __actually__ received a TCP packet, containing RST, but from client's side of view it could look like the server has received it and was sending data after it.

I'll try to take a look at it, but as far as I can see it'll require me to create a test case for it (perhaps, with usage of `ipfw`). Unfortunately, I don't have much time to work on it, but if you wish - we could come up with something usable together.

Though, I should mention that from short-look at code I could say that the SPDY server should stop sending data if it has received the RST, when had some buffered data.

One last question: what node-spdy version are you using?
comments.content:
The question is, how much of the data was __actually__ sent by the server, before it has received the RST. Considering the latency, it could be that server has sent most of the data (or all of it) and only then __actually__ received a TCP packet, containing RST, but from client's side of view it could look like the server has received it and was sending data after it.

I'll try to take a look at it, but as far as I can see it'll require me to create a test case for it (perhaps, with usage of `ipfw`). Unfortunately, I don't have much time to work on it, but if you wish - we could come up with something usable together.

Though, I should mention that from short-look at code I could say that the SPDY server should stop sending data if it has received the RST, when had some buffered data.

One last question: what node-spdy version are you using?
comments.author: indutny

comments.content: And thanks for letting me know!

I did some further testing of this with a larger file, and it is working correctly, in that the stream stops before it finishes sending the file.

But it does seem to send a lot of data before stopping, sending 114 data packets of size 8184 and size 8 interleaving consistently over 780ms from first to last.

doc.body:
Here is a SPDY session for a file that then has a SPDY push to push another file.

The browser immediately sends the RESET STREAM for the SPDY push resource because it is already in cache, but the push stream then continues providing data, long past the latency time (the server is within 100 miles from my location).

The connection starts at 1.570. There is a push stream at 2.282, which is immediately RESET. Until 2.605,  the push stream continues providing data until the stream is complete.

The average latency is around 40ms to the server. So it looks like the server isn't responding to the RESET message.

doc.content:
Here is a SPDY session for a file that then has a SPDY push to push another file.

The browser immediately sends the RESET STREAM for the SPDY push resource because it is already in cache, but the push stream then continues providing data, long past the latency time (the server is within 100 miles from my location).

The connection starts at 1.570. There is a push stream at 2.282, which is immediately RESET. Until 2.605,  the push stream continues providing data until the stream is complete.

The average latency is around 40ms to the server. So it looks like the server isn't responding to the RESET message.

comments.body:
https://gist.github.com/RushPL/8146032
Testing with node 0.11.10-pre from git

Requests do fail when running https://localhost:40443
http://x.rushbase.net/0b8c59d7b7bef7812fa52a4e2f1ec953400a8f01/spdyfail.png
Everything is working when running https://localhost:40444 (but ONLY if https is running different config.ssl - I think that node-spdy may be breaking the TLS setup somehow) 

Try changing `config2.ssl` in my gist to `config.ssl`. `:40444` will be broken as well then. Very weird. I think it says that SPDY itself is not broken but somehow SPDY's negotiation is breaking things as testing with broken SNI/SPDY negotiation to HTTPS problem occurs as well. 

I have not tried node-spdy client since it needs many concurrent requests for the test to make sense.

comments.author: RushPL

comments.body:
@RushPL I fixed `config.ssl` problem. But that other problem seems to be happening on Chromium's side.

I.e. it terminates connection if the server is sending response before the client has finished sending body. You can fix it in your code by waiting for `req.on('end', ...)` to happen (NOTE that in node v0.10 and v0.11 you'll need to read from the request stream in order to received 'end' event).

Unfortunately, this doesn't seem to be something that should be fixed on a node-spdy side. I've contacted chromium guys and will try to resolve issue with them.

(Also it seems to be working fine in firefox for me)
comments.content:
@RushPL I fixed `config.ssl` problem. But that other problem seems to be happening on Chromium's side.

I.e. it terminates connection if the server is sending response before the client has finished sending body. You can fix it in your code by waiting for `req.on('end', ...)` to happen (NOTE that in node v0.10 and v0.11 you'll need to read from the request stream in order to received 'end' event).

Unfortunately, this doesn't seem to be something that should be fixed on a node-spdy side. I've contacted chromium guys and will try to resolve issue with them.

(Also it seems to be working fine in firefox for me)
comments.author: indutny

comments.body: Here is a chromium issue link for your reference: https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=330860&thanks=330860&ts=1388159295
comments.content: Here is a chromium issue link for your reference: https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=330860&thanks=330860&ts=1388159295
comments.author: indutny

comments.body:
Well, I suggest re-opening the issue until google chrome fixes it because for all practical purposes all parties should make an effort to make a protocol work. Problem is that node-spdy is unusable in Chrome which is a major problem - and hence still an open issue. Every client and every server has some "quirks" and parties often meet in the middle. It is my understanding that whatever works with `https.createServer` should work with `spdy.createServer` and hence your `req.on("end")` advice is impractical since I am using for example third party libraries (`node-http-proxy`) which require correct behaviour. Replacing https for spdy simply must work for all use cases for your library to be useful. I applaud your effort but let's try to make it work even better.

About firefox - I am sure there is still some major problem, I will try to update the test case.

comments.author: RushPL

comments.body:
Well, I'm against reopening this issue and working at around for chromium. Fixing it will introduce major problems for some active node-spdy users that I'm currently consulting.

In my opinion - no hacks in node-spdy just to make non-standard compliant clients works. Even if they are popular clients.

Anyway, considering their release process we may get working chrome version quite soon, if they'll consider working on fixing that issue.

comments.body: If that's Chromium problem, then I agree working it around is not a good idea. However, I'd still suggest to open this issue and rename to something like "resources sometimes don't load in Chromium", and keep it open as long as it's not fixed in Chromium. node-spdy users would know in advance that node-spdy should not be used yet when visitors are going to use Chromium. Also, doing so could prevent possible duplicates from being reported.

Firstly, I am using node 0.11.9 (will try git) and node-http-proxy#caronte to get the content. I am sure it works all right, I have no problems with it with ordinary https or http. However with node-spdy it seems that the data is being cut in the middle of some requests. Firebug shows lots of requests and aborted and Chrome seems to work a bit better, but flawed as well. While running into problems I get few types of exceptions. I will try to make some "minimal" testcase but I would like to know your opinion as soon as you could give one.

This is the url being run with node-spdy: https://jira-nowaker.atlashost.eu:8443/secure/Dashboard.jspa <- with Firefox it is most apparent and with Chrome it sometimes requires a few refreshes 

```
[Uncought exception] TypeError: Property 'onIncoming' of object #<HTTPParser> is not a function
    at HTTPParser.parserOnHeadersComplete (_http_common.js:111:23)
    at Socket.socketOnData (_http_client.js:272:20)
    at Socket.EventEmitter.emit (events.js:98:17)
    at readableAddChunk (_stream_readable.js:156:16)
    at Socket.Readable.push (_stream_readable.js:123:10)
    at TCP.onread (net.js:509:20)

doc.body:
I've tried using node-spdy for both client and servers, and I see that although the server appears to be able to fallback to https, the client doesn't, giving the error:

Error: No supported SPDY version

The project readme file doesn't appear to reflect this is the case, and there aren't any examples of usage outside of the Readme file.

Is this definitely the case?

Is there a reasonable way of making this work in the protocol, that node-spdy can be adapted to use?
doc.content:
I've tried using node-spdy for both client and servers, and I see that although the server appears to be able to fallback to https, the client doesn't, giving the error:

Error: No supported SPDY version

The project readme file doesn't appear to reflect this is the case, and there aren't any examples of usage outside of the Readme file.

Is this definitely the case?

Is there a reasonable way of making this work in the protocol, that node-spdy can be adapted to use?
